Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Early <AndroidAsset> caching results in differences w.r.t. other platforms, use case limits." (#1150) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Extract the attached workspace, load the top-level solution.
2. For each of the four client projects (under Clients solution folder), build and run.
3. Observe the on-screen text (Android, iOS, UWP) or command line output (CLI).

[BuildArtifacts.zip](https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-android/files/1598945/BuildArtifacts.zip)

<!--
If you have a repro project, you may drag & drop the .zip/etc. onto the issue editor to attach it.
-->

### Expected Behavior

In all cases, "This is actual content for asset A." is indicated.

### Actual Behavior

For all of { CLI, iOS, UWP }, "This is actual content for asset A." is indicated.
For { Android }, "This is a placeholder for asset A." is indicated.

(Further commentary to follow.)

### Version Information

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[Xamarin.Android.Build.Tasks] ReOrder when Assets are Processed." (#1161) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
Context #1150

The way the current system works is that the `UpdateAndroidAssets`
target is called as part of the `ResolveReferencesDependsOn`. This
makes it impossible to do any kind of processing of assets after
the project has already built. It also menas that a straight up
call to `Build` will result in all the assets being copied into
the intermediate directory. If your project has a large number
of assets that is going to take time. Note this might also be
called as part of a designtime build at the moment... not good.

So is there a reason why we call `UpdateAndroidAssets` before
`Compile`? We don't generate any entries in the Designer.cs files
for them.. We don't clean them up.. we dont appear to do anything
except package them! So the anser looks to be a resounding NO!

So we shall move the `UpdateAndroidAssets` to be part of the
`_CreateBaseApkDependsOnTargets`. This means they will be
processed just before we create the base apk. This will
occur after compilation has completed. So we have a win win..

This commit also includes a unit test which does some post processing
after the `Compile` target to update an asset, it makes sure that
post processing does work.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "ResolveAssemblies tasks uses reference assemblies" (#1162) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Get and Build repro https://github.com/marcominerva/XamarinAndroidIssue

If you instead the build log you will see that 

```
Using "ResolveAssemblies" task from assembly "/Library/Frameworks/Mono.framework/External/xbuild/Xamarin/Android/Xamarin.Android.Build.Tasks.dll".
```

has few `...ref/netstandard2.0/...` references which is wrong as they should never be used as an input to linker or any post compilation processing

This issue is possibly related to #1154 

<!--
If you have a repro project, you may drag & drop the .zip/etc. onto the issue editor to attach it.
-->

### Expected Behavior

No error during execution.

### Actual Behavior

[Mono] Assembly Loader probing location: 'System.Memory'.
[monodroid-assembly] Could not load assembly 'System.Memory' during startup registration.

### Version Information

<!--
1. On macOS and within Visual Studio, select Visual Studio > About Visual Studio, then click the Show Details button, then click the Copy Information button.

2. Paste below this comment block.
-->

Xamarin.Android
Version: 8.1.0.25 (Visual Studio Community)
Android SDK: /Users/marek/Library/Developer/Xamarin/android-sdk-macosx
	Supported Android versions:
		6.0 (API level 23)
		7.1 (API level 25)

SDK Tools Version: 25.2.5
SDK Platform Tools Version: 25.0.5
SDK Build Tools Version: 25.0.3


### Log File

<!--
1. On macOS and within Visual Studio:
    a. Click **Tools** > **SDK Command Prompt**.
    b. Within the launched `Terminal.app` window, run:

            adb logcat -d | pbcopy

2. Paste below this comment block
-->

   ```
/Library/Frameworks/Mono.framework/External/xbuild/Xamarin/Android/Xamarin.Android.Common.targets(1500,2): warning : Ignoring /Users/marek/.nuget/packages/system.buffers/4.4.0/ref/netstandard2.0 as it is a Reference Assembly
/Library/Frameworks/Mono.framework/External/xbuild/Xamarin/Android/Xamarin.Android.Common.targets(1500,2): warning : Ignoring /Users/marek/.nuget/packages/system.memory/4.4.0-preview2-25405-01/ref/netstandard2.0 as it is a Reference Assembly
/Library/Frameworks/Mono.framework/External/xbuild/Xamarin/Android/Xamarin.Android.Common.targets(1500,2): warning : Ignoring /Users/marek/.nuget/packages/system.runtime.compilerservices.unsafe/4.4.0/ref/netstandard2.0 as it is a Reference Assembly
```

<!--
Switch to the "Preview" tab to ensure your issue renders correctly.

Please add an appropriate "Area:" label in the Labels section.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[Xamarin.Android.Build.Tasks] ReOrder when Assets are Processed." (#1161) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
Context #1150

The way the current system works is that the `UpdateAndroidAssets`
target is called as part of the `ResolveReferencesDependsOn`. This
makes it impossible to do any kind of processing of assets after
the project has already built. It also menas that a straight up
call to `Build` will result in all the assets being copied into
the intermediate directory. If your project has a large number
of assets that is going to take time. Note this might also be
called as part of a designtime build at the moment... not good.

So is there a reason why we call `UpdateAndroidAssets` before
`Compile`? We don't generate any entries in the Designer.cs files
for them.. We don't clean them up.. we dont appear to do anything
except package them! So the anser looks to be a resounding NO!

So we shall move the `UpdateAndroidAssets` to be part of the
`_CreateBaseApkDependsOnTargets`. This means they will be
processed just before we create the base apk. This will
occur after compilation has completed. So we have a win win..

This commit also includes a unit test which does some post processing
after the `Compile` target to update an asset, it makes sure that
post processing does work.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[WIP] Sanitize Xamarin.Android.sln: fix several inconsistency bits." (#1159) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
Manually editing solution file is uncool and error prone, but since the
entire xamarin-android source tree is not designed cleanly it is impossible
to use IDEs to do the right job.

As stated at https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-android/issues/1129 ,
we should eliminate this Xamarin.Android.sln as a source file and it should
be only generated, not directly committed to the tree. But to achieve that
we first need to find the right structure and right content.

So far, there were handful of issues that either missed or incorrectly
added solution items with inconsistent configurations.

These inconsistent parts were found by the solution content analyzer at
https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-android/issues/1129#issuecomment-355484902

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Implicit Styles in Resources do not override Styles in MergedDictionaries" (#1523) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
Bug report best practices: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/wiki/Submitting-Issues

### Description
*Implicit* styles defined in MergedDictionaries resources could not be overridden with implicit styles defined in the Resource. It does work for explicit styles.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. In ResourceDictionary (A) create style 

<Style TargetType="Button">
    <Setter Property="Background" Value="Red" />
</Button>

2. In ResourceDictionary (B) create style

<Style TargetType="Button">
    <Setter Property="Background" Value="Blue" />
</Button>

3. In ResourceDictionary (B) in MergedDictionaries add ResourceDictionary (A)

4. Create new Page and assign page.Resources = ResourceDictionary (B)

5. Add a button on the page
<Grid><Button/></Grid>

### Expected Behavior
Button Background color should be Blue.

### Actual Behavior
Button Background color is Red.

### Basic Information
- Version with issue: Xamarin.Forms 2.5.0.121934

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[UWP] Extension methods for Color ToWindowsColor() and ToBrush() not accessible" (#1522) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
### Description
The ``ToWindowsColor()`` and `ToBrush()`` extension methods for Color are not available on UWP because the static class ConvertExtensions in which they are found is ``internal`` instead of ``public``
See : https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/blob/master/Xamarin.Forms.Platform.UAP/ConvertExtensions.cs#L6

Also, less important but all other implementations of this function on other platforms are in a class named ColorExtensions, I suggest renaming it to be more consistent.

### Steps to Reproduce

### Expected Behavior

The static class should be public instead of internal, so that those methods can be used outside of Xamarin.Forms, especially useful for renderers.

### Actual Behavior

Extension methods cannot be used.

### Basic Information

### Screenshots


### Reproduction Link

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed pull request "Rename ConvertExtensions to ColorExtensions and change access to public" (#1521) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
### Description of Change ###
Color extensions to convert a Forms Color to a UWP color / brush are not accessible since the class is marked as internal instead of public. I also renamed the class to ColorExtensions to be consistent with all other platforms.

### Bugs Fixed ###
Could not use ToWindowsColor or ToBrush in UWP Forms renderers.

### API Changes ###

List all API changes here (or just put None), example:

Changed:
 - internal static class ConvertExtensions => public static class ColorExtensions

### Behavioral Changes ###

### PR Checklist ###
I don't think this requires tests?

- [ ] Has tests (if omitted, state reason in description)
- [x] Rebased on top of master at time of PR
- [x] Changes adhere to coding standard
- [x] Consolidate commits as makes sense

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Forms Map resets back to last set region on resizing" (#1520) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
Bug report best practices: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/wiki/Submitting-Issues

### Description
When the forms map control is resized, the map's region is set to the LastMoveToRegion which is not the current region of the map (as the user has panned / zoomed after the MoveToRegion method was called).  This is because the LastMoveToRegion is not updated based on user action.

I observed this both on iOS and Android. 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a Forms Map with a preset region.
2. Pan / zoom the map to a different region.
3. Resize the forms map (using  code) or change the orientation of the mobile. 

### Expected Behavior
1. The map control should expand / shrink based on the new size but the center coordinates / zoom level should be retained. 

### Actual Behavior
2. It resets to the last value set with the MoveToRegion method. 

### Basic Information

- Version with issue: 2.3.4 ( but the issue exists in the latest version as well )
- Last known good version:
- IDE:
- Platform Target Frameworks: <!-- All that apply -->
  - iOS:  <!-- The version of the iOS SDK you are compiling against, e.g. 11.1 -->
  - Android: <!-- The version of the Android SDK you are compiling against, e.g. 7.1 --> 
- Android Support Library Version: <!-- if applicable -->
- Nuget Packages:
- Affected Devices:

### Screenshots

<!-- If the issue is a visual issue, please include screenshots showing the problem if possible -->

### Reproduction Link

<!-- Please upload or provide a link to a reproduction case -->

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Can't scroll to end of viewcell inside a listview if after content changed!" (#1519) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
Bug report best practices: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/wiki/Submitting-Issues

### Description

I have a ListView with many elements, each of them has some text and a hidden StackLayout. On tapped event i make the StackLayouts visible so the ViewCell's height changes, and i want to make the whole content visible, so i try listView.ScrollTo(viewCell, ScrollToPosition.End, false); but it does nothing, i assume the new ending position of the layout is unknown and it prevents to function to work as expected.

### Expected Behavior

Somehow get the new end position to supply it to the ScrollTo() method

### Actual Behavior

see above

### Basic Information

- Version with issue: ALL
- Last known good version: n/a
- IDE: VS2017 Professional 15.5.2
- Platform Target Frameworks:
  - Android: 7.1 
- Android Support Library Version: 26.1.0.1
- Nuget Packages: Xamarin.Forms 2.5.0.121934
- Affected Devices: ALL

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "No view found for id 0x9 (unknown) for fragment FragmentContainer" (#1518) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Opened issue "Runtime XAML binding errors logged but not viewable" (#1517) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
[BindingExpression.ApplyCore](https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/blob/master/Xamarin.Forms.Core/BindingExpression.cs) calls `Log.Warning` if there's a runtime problem with XAML. However, these errors never show up in Visual Studio for Windows.

When debugging using Visual Studio for Windows, any binding errors should minimally show up in the Output Window in the Debug section. Even better would be an option to break execution when such a warning occurs.

The problem occurs with at least UWP and iOS.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[metalperformanceshaders] Fix MPSImageLanczosScale base class change" (#3170) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
Sadly this creates a breaking change since the `ScaleTransform`
property was re-introduced with an incorrect signature in the new
base class `MPSImageScale`

Unless someone has an idea how to avoid it (I don't see an option)
then we'll have to document it in the 15.7 release notes.
